name: Inventory & Audit
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: A content inventory is a list of all the content attached to the project, including the application, documentation, images and any other assets. A content audit is an evaluation of that inventory to determine what needs improving, removing or left as is. Once both steps are complete you should have a good understanding of the current state of the project and potential ways to move forward.

content.title: Benefits
list: Understand existing content better, improving future maintenance
Helps to understand the scope of the project and find assets you didn't know existed
Useful for creating a strategy going forwards
Web analytics give a better idea of content effectiveness
Helps with ensure content aligns with both business goals and user needs

content.title: Prerequisites
list: None!

content.title: The Process
ordered: List all project assets, including files, pages, images
Document data associated with those files, including content type, goal, metadata, analytics
Document who owns the content if content is shared
Document page links when looking to improve navigation
Review each asset against for quality, consistency, performance, if it meets its goal, duplication etc
Review the status of each asset, does it need updating, deleting or is it ok as it is?
Prioritise actions based on user wants and client requests

content.title: Deliverables
list: A full project inventory
A project inventory audit evaluating what needs improving or removing
A report

content.title: Content Audit
content.caption: An example audit list

content.title: Priority Order
content.caption: With a content inventory and user/stakeholder requirements defined, work can be prioritised

name: Stakeholder Interviews
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: Interviews with project stakeholders offer useful insights into the collective mind of an organization. They can help you uncover areas of misalignment between a company’s documented strategy and the attitudes and day-to-day decision-making of stakeholders. They can also highlight issues that deserve special consideration due to their strategic importance to a business.

content.title: Benefits
list: Determine the business goals
Find out what is already known about the users
Learn the stakeholder’s background and story
Discover the currently known competitors
Find out about an technological or any other limitations

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Content Inventory & Audit - gives insight into existing product

content.title: The Process
ordered: Determine a list of stakeholders to interview, including senior, SMEs, marketing, sales and engineering
Create a list of questions for each stakeholder, limited to four major topics
Let interviewees know in advance what you’ll ask them, or at least the topics you plan to discuss
Prepare any useful documents found in the content inventory, including annual reports, strategy document, advertisements etc
Set aside at least 45 minutes for each interview
Discuss the culture, challenges and goals, not the features
Document the outcomes of each interview

content.title: Deliverables
list: Individual stakeholder interview notes
Summary document providing overview of picture built from all interviews

content.title: Stakeholder Interview Questions
content.caption: Create a questions library to produce personalised interviews from

name: User Interviews
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: User interviews allow you to speak directly to users and get responses to specific questions that you have. If done well, it could also uncover nuances or directions that were previously unknown or unthought of. Very often it is the most powerful way to find a truth about their behaviour (backed up with stories) that you otherwise may not consider.

content.title: Benefits
list: Get answers to outstanding questions
Discover directions not previously considered
Get a perspective outside the companies internal views
Gather knowledge required to generate user stories, personas and use cases

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Stakeholder Interviews - to determine how user needs align with stakeholder goals

content.title: The Process
ordered: Know what you want answered
Reframe the problem statements
Build a list of non-leading, open-ended questions
Give the list of questions a structure (intro, warm-up, main-body and wrap-up)
Document the outcomes of each interview

content.title: Deliverables
list: Individual user interview notes
A list of user scenarios

content.title: User Interview Summary
content.caption: Summary of a user interview

name: Competitive Analysis
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: To identify your competitors and evaluate their strategies to determine their strengths and weaknesses relative to those of your own product or service. This will help to identify compelling competitive advantages that could be introduced as well as a good market fit. Remember this solution needs to feel organic to your users’ needs, while being clear to all involved how the competitor research has informed it.

content.title: Benefits
list: Learn what solutions others offer
Learn what others do well and not so well
Learn what mistakes others have previously made
Helps determine where your current solution fits
Helps to identify what your solution needs to offer

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Content Inventory & Audit - gives insight into existing product
Stakeholder Interviews – gives insight to unique business goals
User Interviews – gives insight to user needs

content.title: The Process
ordered: Define the competition including direct and indirect competitors
Define the assessment criteria
Conduct the research by filling out a spreadsheet containing the competitors against the the assessment criteria
Summarise your findings
Present your findings

content.title: Deliverables
list: An in-depth analysis of each of the identified competitors’ products
Screenshots along with annotations explaining the specifics of each feature/UX flow
Feature list and/or approximate sitemap of each competitor’s platform/product
Strengths and areas of improvement for each of the analyzed products
Competitor analysis matrix — A table that contains a column for features and separate columns for if each competitor has that feature

content.title: Competitor Analysis Matrix
content.caption: Competitor Analysis Matrix

name: Persona Workshop
step: Model experiences, tasks and mindsets for goals, and define and frame the problem

content.title: Goal
content.text: A persona is a way to model, summarise and communicate research about people in a condensed way. Each persona represents a significant number of people in the real world but is depicted as a specific person. This enables designers to focus on a manageable and memorable cast of characters, instead of focusing on thousands of individuals and helps with creating different designs for different people.

content.title: Benefits
list: Builds empathy with users
Develops focus by having clear user types to develop for
Helps communicate interview findings with others in a concise way
Helps to defend decisions made based on real data

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Interviews

content.title: The Process
ordered: Ensure enough users have been interviewed
Find patterns in responses and actions and use those to group similar people together
Create archetypical models of those groups based on the patterns found, including demographic info, backgrounds, goals, motivations and pain points
Share those models with other team members and stakeholders

content.title: Deliverables
list: A handful of personas summarising the user base

content.title: Persona Demographic
content.caption: Persona Demographic

content.title: Persona Background
content.caption: Persona Background

content.title: Persona Goals
content.caption: Persona Goals

content.title: Persona Motivations
content.caption: Persona Motivations

content.title: Persona Further Info
content.caption: Persona Further Info

name: Journey Mapping
step: Model experiences, tasks and mindsets for goals, and define and frame the problem

content.title: Goal
content.text: A User Journey is used to visualise a structured narrative of what a user does, thinks and feels. This can be used to review the current user experience, identify gaps, pain points and opportunities to improve things where possible.

content.title: Benefits
list: Builds empathy with users
Helps to document full user flows for each of their goals
Identify potential points of improvement in the user experience

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Interviews
Personas

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather previously defined user scenarios and personas into one place
For each persona draw out the each scenario/task the user completes to achieve their goal
Analyse interview notes and personas for each task and write out what the user is thinking and how they are feeling
Identify pain points in the flow
Brainstorm potential solutions to these pain points

content.title: Deliverables
list: A journey map for each personas summarising their workflow
A list of potential opportunities to improve different user experiences

content.title: Journey Mapping Template
content.caption: A template for creating a User Journey Map

content.title: Journey Mapping Example
content.caption: An example of how a User Journey looks once complete

name: Event Storming
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: Event storming is a rapid design technique that establishes a common and shared language between Business & IT. It sets focus in terms of scope and boundaries and gives you the big picture of the solution by placing technical implementation details in context of the business process. It will also help identify key views for your user interface, which can jump start Site Mapping and Wireframing.

content.title: Benefits
list: Share understanding about business objectives and project/product goals
Supports group learning and is a fun way to integrate development and product teams
Help the development team get to know the client’s business better
Can help to identify bottlenecks and areas of conflict

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping

content.title: The Process
ordered: Invite a mixture of stakeholders representing user experience, business, architecture, development, and IT
Provide unlimited modeling space
Using previously gathered personas and journeys, explore the business domain by identifying domain events
Evaluate each event for its causes and consequences (commands)
Connect events to reactions, what happens as a result of the event
Use domain-driven design to define the structure of your system
This process can be repeated working on what had been completed in the previous session with different stakeholders

content.title: Deliverables
list: An event-driven system model containing UI requirements and data models
A unified view and language between all parts of the organisation

content.title: Event Storming Domain Events
content.caption: Start of be listing out domain events

content.title: Event Storming Commands
content.caption: Add commands to events to list causes and consequences

content.title: Event Storming Reactions
content.caption: Add reactions to events to list what happens as a result of the event

content.title: Event Storming Business Process
content.caption: Define the business process by structuring the result of the previous steps

content.title: Event Storming Example
content.caption: An example of what Event Storming can look like

name: Story Mapping
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: A technique completed collaboratively to help visualise the project scope and create a backlog by mapping out the user stories with regards to complete user journeys. The activity should involve the designers, developers, product owner and ideally any stakeholders and SMEs in order to bridge the gap between design and development. Seeing the bigger picture helps to determine priorities and prevent focusing too much on individual stories.

content.title: Benefits
list: Visualise how all user stories link together
Gain a unified agreement of the project scope and priority
Designers understand risks and feasibility and developers understand user goals
Focuses on helping users achieve their goals rather than on adding features

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping
Event Storming

content.title: The Process
ordered: Set up a list of participants
Identify and discuss user and business goals
Discuss User Personas and how the new product will be beneficial over existing solutions
Create narrative flows, breaking down goals into features, features into epics (user tasks) and epics into user stories
Break down user stories into tasks and sub-tasks where necessary
Consider additional paths and variations, including errors and edge cases
Slice user stories and tasks into releases using Red Route Analysis

content.title: Deliverables
list: A user story map containing stories and tasks grouped and prioritised into releases

content.title: Story Mapping layout
content.caption: Example layout

content.title: Story Mapping alternative layout
content.caption: An alternative layout

content.title: Story Map Slicing
content.caption: Breaking down user stories into releases

content.title: Red Route Analysis
content.caption: Use Red Route Analysis to help slice up user stories into releases

content.title: Goal
content.text: A Sitemap is a hierarchical diagram showing the structure of an application. They ensure content is in a logical place that users would expect to find it and can be used as a reference point for wireframes and user flows.

content.title: Benefits
list: Show how the navigation should be structured
Help identify where content fits and what needs to be produced
Clearly display the relationship between different pages

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Personas
Journey Mapping
Event Storming
Story Mapping

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather data from previous mapping activities. Ideally a lot of the work will already be done!
If details are missing run a card sort session, writing down all page names on cards and sort them into categories
From all gathered information create an initial mindmap with a hierarchical view of all pages
Review this diagram against documented User Journeys to ensure the taxonomy support them
Review whether all personas understand the labelling you have come up with
Review if there are any categories that are too large or small and break them up where necessary
Pages can then be ordered in terms of user interaction order to produce a Site Flow diagram if not too complex

content.title: Deliverables
list: A Sitemap diagram that demonstrates the navigation layout and organisation of content
A Site Flow diagram, showing roughly the order of user interaction for each page in a category

content.title: Sitemap Example
content.caption: An example Sitemap

content.title: Site Flow Example
content.caption: An example Site Flow

content.title: Goal
content.text: A User Flow is a sequence of steps the user needs to take in order to accomplish a task inside the application. Visualising these sequences helps to improve and simplify an existing process, or design an optimised flow and determine what information is required. ?It also helps to eliminate guesswork and ambiguity for the developer.

content.title: Benefits
list: Helps to determine if the current process is complete or if steps are missing
Discover if the design can be simplified and whether the number of steps reduced
Determine if each next step is obvious enough, or if further information is required
Provides documentation for all user interactions

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping
Event Storming
Sitemap Diagram

content.title: The Process
ordered: First list out all entry points into the application and possible landing pages
For each persona create user flows using only text
Each step should state what the user sees and what they do to progress to the next step
Start with happy paths, then move onto edge cases and error paths
From these flows draw sketches representing the UI so that each step can be more easily visualised
Once confirmed these sketches can be digitised

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of diagrams documenting all user interactions with the application

content.title: User Flow initial steps
content.caption: Initial text only user flow steps

content.title: User Flow Direction
content.caption: User flows should only go in one direction and show possible outcomes

content.title: User Flow Breakdown
content.caption: Flows should be broken down to show how individual goals are met

content.title: Example User Flow
content.caption: An example User Flow diagram

content.title: Goal
content.text: Wireframing is a way to design an application interface at the structural level. A wireframe is commonly used to lay out content and functionality on a page based on the previously defined User Flows. Wireframes help establish the basic structure of a page before visual design and content is added. Wireflows are used to show the relationship or flow between pages, while Interaction (IX) Flows define each interactive element’s trigger, feedback, rules, and loops/modes.

content.title: Benefits
list: Conveys the overall direction and description of the user interface
A quick way to review and amend the structure of key pages based on user and business needs
Great way of getting feedback from users and stakeholders
IX Flows centralise the flow, visual design, and interactions in one document
Reduces guesswork and ambiguity on the developer’s part

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Event Storming
User Flows
Sitemap Diagram

content.title: The Process
ordered: Based on the previously defined User Flows, mock up a wireframes for every page containing the key elements required by users to complete those flows
Consider usability conventions, spacing and information hierarchy while designing wireframes

Once wireframes have been completed Wireflows can be created by connecting each wireframe together with arrows to display user interactions and how their workflow causes them to navigate between pages
Once all Wireflows have been completed a single Interaction flow can be produced

Create a reference panel that defines the types of gestures and their representative symbols, definitions for terms used when describing interactions and a legend that defines the flow lines and other symbols
Insert your wireframes with enough space for arrows and containers to fit around them

For each wireframe interactive element add a reference box listing: the name and trigger with the matching icon, what feedback the user receives, what rules there are for what can and cannot be done and any different modes the element supports
Connect wireframes with lines for connections between screens

content.title: Deliverables
list: A series of individual wireframes for each core page of the application
A series of Wireflows documenting the interactions between wireframes
A single Interaction Flow documenting each interactive element’s trigger, feedback, rules, and loops/modes

content.title: Wireframe Example
content.caption: A wireframe example

content.title: Another Wireframe Example
content.caption: Another wireframe example

content.title: Wireflow
content.caption: An example of a Wireflow

content.title: Another Wireflow
content.caption: Another example of a Wireflow

content.title: IX Flow Reference Panel
content.caption: An example of an Interaction Flow reference panel

content.title: IX Flow Wireframe
content.caption: An example of how a wireframe fits into an Interaction Flow

content.title: IX Flow Reference Box
content.caption: An example of an Interaction Flow reference box

content.title: IX Flow Complete
content.caption: An complete example of an Interaction Flow

content.title: Goal
content.text: Style Tiles consist of fonts, colors and interface elements that communicate the essence of a visual brand. They help form a common visual language between the designers and the stakeholders and provide a catalyst for discussions around the preferences and goals of the client.

content.title: Benefits
list: Help to nail down a specific aesthetic
Establish a direct connection with actual interface elements without defining layout
Help translate established brands smoothly to an interface
Quick to produce without the need to create an entire style guide

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Stakeholder Interviews
Event Storming

content.title: The Process
ordered: Research any existing company branding
Have a design kickoff meeting involving stakeholders to get design ideas
Interpret how the adjectives and themes discovered translate into design principles, such as balance and emphasis
Determine themes from the aggregated adjectives and begin to match them up with styles
Present multiple tiles and gather feedback for production of a new set of times
Continue creating refined style tiles until an accepted core design language is agreed upon

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of potential style tiles
An agreed style tile that defines the core design language going forwards

content.title: Style Tile Example
content.caption: A Style Tile example

content.title: Another Style Tile Example
content.caption: Another Style Tile example

content.title: A Further Style Tile Example
content.caption: Yet another Style Tile example

content.title: Goal
content.text: Design Systems encompass Style Guides (that define abstract styles) and Pattern Libraries (that define usable blocks) and also focus on defining rules and connections of an application. The goal is to create an asset that will stand the test of time, is open for additions and is accessible for anyone new to dive right into the guide with ease. In some cases a full Design System is required, in other cases a basic Style Guide will do.

content.title: Benefits
list: Record all design elements and interactions that occur within the application
List crucial UI components such as buttons, typography, color and navigation menus
Document important UX components like hover states, dropdown fills and animations
Contain live elements and code snippets for developers to reference and use

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Style Tile Design

content.title: The Process
ordered: Create an existing UI inventory, including patterns, colors, typography, icons and spacing layouts
Review the state of the existing inventory to discover inconsistencies, UX problems or issues negatively affecting the software development process
Discuss with stakeholders the need for either a Style Guide, Pattern Library or Design System to eliminate raised issues
Determine the technologies being used for the application and agree the best tools to use going forward
If creating a Style Guide define the color palette, typography, icons and page structuring
If creating a Pattern Library define reusable components, such as buttons, notifications, tables and forms
If creating a Design System define the application rules and connections including motion, accessibility and taxonomies
All these documents should be living and are not expected to cover all possibilities going forward. If new features are required later in development the Design System can be updated

content.title: Deliverables
list: A defined Style Guide defining abstract styles
A defined Pattern Library defining usable blocks
A defined Design System defining rules and connections

content.title: Design System Overview
content.caption: How Style Guides, Pattern Library and Design System relate to each other

content.title: Style Guide
content.caption: An example Style Guide

content.title: Another Style Guide
content.caption: Another Style Guide example

content.title: Pattern Library
content.caption: An example Pattern Library

content.title: Design System
content.caption: An example Design System

content.title: Another Design System
content.caption: Another example of a Design System

content.title: Yet Another Design System
content.caption: Yet another example of a Design System

content.title: Goal
content.text: High Fidelity Mockups are more complete representations of the application interface than Wireframes. The previously created Design System can be used to drag in elements and quickly produce an interface the very closely resembles the finished product. These mockups can even be made clickable and respond to the user’s actions, mimicking authentic interface interaction.

content.title: Benefits
list: Provides a clear idea as to how the interface will look and work
Perfect for testing and gaining accurate feedback from the client
Less likely to have errors when testing than a coded prototype

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Wireframes & IX Flows
Design Systems

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather previously designed wireframes and have the Design System at hand
For each wireframe update the content following the Style Guide and using the components documented in the Design System
Decide on software that mimics user interaction and connect the new High Fidelity Mockups using the defined IX Flows

content.title: Deliverables
list: A set of High Fidelity Mockups for each previously produced Wireframe using the Design System
A interactive demo with simulated clickable links between pages

content.title: High Fidelity Mockup Example
content.caption: A High Fidelity Mockup example

content.title: Another High Fidelity Mockup Example
content.caption: Another High Fidelity Mockup example

content.title: Goal
content.text: A/B Testing, or Split Testing, is the method of comparing two versions of an application against each other to determine which one performs better. A/B testing is an experiment where two or more variants of a page are shown to users at random and statistical analysis is used to determine which variation performs better for a given goal.

content.title: Benefits
list: Enables changes to the user experience to be made while collecting data on the results
Helps to understand why certain elements of the experiences impact user behavior
Opinion about the best experience for a given goal can be proven wrong
Takes the guesswork out of website optimization
Can be used consistently to continually improve a given experience, improving a single goal conversion rate over time

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Flow Diagrams
Wireframes & IX Flows or High Fidelity Mockups

content.title: The Process
ordered: Formulate a hypothesis based on web analytics and analysis of visitors’ actions, i.e. 'users rarely click on the “Buy” button'
Identify targets to test this hypothesis on
Select a test item that you can create variations of for testing, such as the button itself, headings etc
Create one or more variations of that item, such as increased size, color, location
If running on a live application determine the duration of the experiment as results may not be immediate
Proceed to the main test comparing variations against the control and analyse the results

content.title: Deliverables
list: A report detailing hypothesis accuracy
Successful and unsuccessful page variants

content.title: AB Testing Stages
content.caption: The stages of A/B Testing

content.title: AB Testing Variation
content.caption: An example of how small changes can boost user interaction

content.title: AB Testing Layout
content.caption: How layout changes can improve user goal success rate

content.title: Goal
content.text: Usability Testing is where you observe someone from your target audience perform tasks using either a digital or prototype version of the application. The user will be prompted with tasks and questions, then they should voice their thoughts and experience allowed. Based on completion time, errors made, satisfactions and ease of use, a measure of how successful the interface is can be determined.

content.title: Benefits
list: Gain qualitative metrics includes time taken on the task, number of clicks, success rate etc.
Gain qualitative metrics includes user satisfaction and behavioral response
Can resolve internal debates on design alternatives
Minimises the risk of the product failing due to poor user experience

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Flow Diagrams
Wireframes & IX Flows or High Fidelity Mockups

content.title: The Process
ordered: Determine the scope and purpose of the test, which assumptions you want to check and what you are trying to measure
Decide how many sessions should be completed and who to invite for each testing session
For each test give the participant an introduction to the process, what the goal is and run through a warm-up task
For each task, ask the participant to think allowed and document their experience and thoughts as they try to complete the goal
Analyse the results and create a test report prioritising the findings (good and bad)
The report can then be used to negotiate the design changes required to improve user experience

content.title: Deliverables
list: Quantitative data on how users interact with the application
A report listing points of failure and potential improvements

content.title: Usability Testing Stages
content.caption: The key stages of Usability Testing

content.title: Usability Testing Plan
content.caption: A simple Usability Testing session plan

content.title: Usability Testing Report
content.caption: A sample test report based on the results of the usability tests

name: Quantitative Survey
step: Visualise user experience results at a larger scale

content.title: Goal
content.text: Surveys can be used to validate qualitative findings found from other forms of testing such as A/B Tests or Usability Tests. They can also be used to gather information about your users, their attitudes and their behaviors. When using established questionnaires results can be compared to industry or competitor scores.

content.title: Benefits
list: Put a number on the usability of the application
Confirm findings from other methods of testing
Cheap and quick for the number of responses received

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Personas
A/B Testing
Usability Testing

content.title: The Process
ordered: Determine research objectives and understand the end goal
Write the first survey draft
Test the survey with pilot users and colleagues to get feedback on the survey
Iterate the survey, then test it and iterate again until you're happy with it
Make sure to target the right participants that match your defined Personas and roll out the final survey
Evaluate survey results and create a report detailing the findings and how they match with previously conducted tests

content.title: Deliverables
list: A series of user survey results
A report detailing the key results of the surveys and how they line up with previously conducted tests

content.title: System Usability Scale
content.caption: The System Usability Scale questionnaire is a quick tool for measuring usability

content.title: System Usability Scale Result
content.caption: The results from the SUS results can be used determine score

content.title: Net Promoter Score
content.caption: Net Promoter Score (NPS) is a metric for assessing customer loyalty for a brand or application

content.title: Completion Rates
content.caption: A binary measure of pass and fail provides a simple metric of success

name: Analytics Review
step: Visualise user experience results at a larger scale

content.title: Goal
content.text: There’s no substitute for getting in a room with users and observing them with the application, but in recent years a number of services have tried to fill the gap that analytics tools that only provide page-views and bounce rates can't fill. The ability to see how users are actually interacting with your website gives priceless feedback.

content.title: Benefits
list: Gain results usually collected as part of usability tests, but without the need for travel
Gain more data faster and cheaper than you could from usability testing
Gain new kinds of data such as visual heat-maps not otherwise available from any other kinds of tests

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Flow Diagrams
Wireframes & IX Flows or High Fidelity Mockups

content.title: The Process
ordered: Decide on the scope and purpose of the tests and what you want to observe and measure
Define what tasks you want users to complete
Setup the tasks using tools such as Hotjar and Crazy Egg that support heat-maps and session recording amongst other features
Test the setup with pilot users and colleagues to get feedback before going live
Determine the target audience and send the created tasks to them
Analyse the results and create a test report prioritising the findings
The report can then be used to negotiate the design changes required to improve user experience

content.title: Deliverables
list: Quantitative data on how users interact with the application
A report listing points of failure and potential improvements

content.title: Analytics Heatmap
content.caption: Tools like Hotjar allow you to view user heatmaps

content.title: Analytics Recordings
content.caption: They also capture screen recordings so user interactions can be analysed

content.title: Analytics Funnels
content.caption: Funnels can be used to view user drop-off and conversion rates as they move through the application

content.title: Analytics Feedback
content.caption: Users can provide feedback on certain elements giving their opinion

content.title: Analytics Polls
content.caption: Feedback polls can also be used to gain a rating on key questions

content.title: Analytics Surveys
content.caption: Surveys can also be integrated and their results easily visualised
